docs.title: 📝 Mini Style Guide
docs.text: This portfolio follows a simple, consistent writing style. The goal: clarity, consistency, and easy scanning.

docs.title: ✍️ Writing style
docs.text:
• Use short, direct sentences (aim for one idea per sentence).
  • Write in the active voice (e.g., Click Save, not The Save button should be clicked).
  • Address the reader with imperatives (“Click…”, “Select…”).
  • Use present tense for steps and descriptions.
  • One action per numbered step.

docs.title: 💻 Formatting rules
docs.text:
• Headings: Use emojis + plain titles (e.g., ## ⚡ Quick Start).
  • Bold for button names, menu paths, or anything the user must click.
  • Example: Click File → Export**
  • Italics for emphasis or placeholders.
  • Example: Enter your Project name**.
  • Code font for commands, file names, or text to type.
  • Example: Save as glossary.csv.

docs.title: 📷 Screenshots
docs.text:
• Crop tightly to show only the relevant area.
  • Add alt text for accessibility.
  • Example: ![Trados New Project wizard](trados-new-project.png)
  • Use arrows or boxes sparingly to highlight UI elements.

docs.title: 🔗 Linking
docs.text:
• Relative links inside the repo (e.g., (quick-start.md) not full URLs).
  • In overviews (README.md), always add a short description after each link.

docs.title: 📅 Maintenance
docs.text:
• Every doc ends with a Last updated line.
  • Add a short version note if content applies to a specific software release.
  • Example: > 🛈 Written using Trados Studio 2017.

Last updated: 4 Sept 2025

docs.title: 🌐 Getting Started with DeepL (Web App)
docs.text:
This mini-documentation set introduces the basics of working with DeepL Translator in the browser. It is designed for translators who want to use DeepL efficiently without needing a paid plan or installation.

🛈 Version note: Written using the DeepL free web app (September 2025). Features may differ in the desktop or Pro versions.

docs.title: 📂 What’s inside
docs.text:
• ⚡ Quick Start — Translate text and documents in 5 steps
  • 📘 How-To: Create and Use a Glossary — Control your terminology
  • 🔧 Troubleshooting — Common problems and fixes

docs.title: 🎯 Purpose
docs.text:
This guide shows how to: - Translate text and documents online - Apply terminology consistently with glossaries - Solve basic problems (e.g., file types, login, glossary limits)

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 📘 Reference: DeepL Glossary Limits (Free vs Pro)
docs.text:
Glossary capacity depends on your DeepL plan.

Source: DeepL Support

Last updated: 4 Sept 2025

docs.title: 📘 How-To: Create and Use a Glossary in DeepL (Web App)
docs.text: Glossaries let you control how specific terms are translated, ensuring consistency.

docs.title: Who this is for
docs.text: Translators who want to enforce preferred terminology in their DeepL translations.

docs.title: What you need
docs.text:
• A free DeepL account (login required)
  • DeepL web app in your browser
  • Source and target languages supported by glossaries (e.g., English ↔ German, English ↔ French)

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Log in to DeepL Go to https://www.deepl.com/translator and sign in.

  2. Open glossary settings

  3. In the top bar, click Glossary.

  4. Select Create glossary.

  5. Add a term pair

  6. Enter the source term (e.g., car).
  7. Enter the preferred translation (e.g., Automobil).

  8. Click Add.

  9. Check your glossary Your glossary list now shows the new entry. Free accounts allow up to 10 entries in one glossary.

  10. Use the glossary

  11. Translate text as usual.
  12. When the source term appears, DeepL automatically applies your glossary translation.

docs.title: Result
docs.text: Your translations now follow your glossary rules, improving consistency and control.

docs.title: If things go wrong
docs.text:
• Glossary doesn’t apply: Make sure the source and target language pair supports glossaries.
  • Can’t add more entries: Free plan allows only 10 entries. Delete one to add another.
  • Glossary option not visible: Ensure you are logged in with a registered DeepL account.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: ⚡ Quick Start: Translate with DeepL (Web App)
docs.text: Get started with DeepL in just a few minutes — no installation required.

docs.title: Who this is for
docs.text: Translators and writers who want to translate short texts or documents directly in the browser.

docs.title: What you need
docs.text:
• A free DeepL account (optional but recommended)
  • A web browser (Chrome, Edge, Firefox, or Safari)
  • Internet connection

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open DeepL in your browser Go to https://www.deepl.com/translator.

  2. Type or paste text Enter your text in the left box (source language).

  3. Choose languages

  4. On the left: select your source language (or let DeepL detect it automatically).

  5. On the right: choose your target language.

  6. View the translation DeepL displays the translated text in the right box instantly.

  7. Translate a document

  8. Click Translate files below the input box.
  9. Upload a Word (.docx) or PowerPoint (.pptx) file.
  10. Download the translated document once ready.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
You’ve successfully translated text or documents using the free DeepL web app.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 🔧 Troubleshooting: DeepL (Web App)
docs.text: Common problems when using the free DeepL translator in a browser, and how to solve them.

docs.title: 1) I can’t log in
docs.text: Cause: Wrong password or using Google/Apple login without linking it to a DeepL account. Fix: - Reset your password at https://www.deepl.com/account/reset-password. - If you usually log in with Google or Apple, make sure to click the matching button on the login screen.

docs.title: 2) My file won’t upload
docs.text: Cause: DeepL free supports only Word (.docx) and PowerPoint (.pptx). Fix: - Convert your file to .docx or .pptx before uploading. - For PDFs, use another tool to convert to Word first.

docs.title: 3) The file is too large
docs.text: Cause: Free accounts have a size limit per document. Fix: - Split the document into smaller sections. - Translate each separately. - Or upgrade to a paid plan for higher limits.

docs.title: 4) Glossary doesn’t apply
docs.text: Cause: Glossaries work only for supported language pairs (e.g., EN–DE, EN–FR). Fix: - Check that your source/target pair supports glossaries. - Make sure you’re logged in, since glossaries are linked to your account. - Free accounts allow only 10 entries — delete one if the glossary is full.

docs.title: 5) The translation is missing formatting
docs.text:
Cause: DeepL sometimes strips complex formatting. Fix: - Simplify the original file before uploading. - Reapply formatting manually after translation.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 🖋️ Getting Started with Trados Studio 2017
docs.text:
This mini-documentation set introduces the basics of working in Trados Studio 2017 for first-time users.

🛈 Version note: Written using Trados Studio 2017. Menu names or screens may differ slightly in newer versions.

docs.title: What’s inside
docs.text:
• ⚡ Quick Start
  • 📘 How-To: Create a Project
  • 🔧 Troubleshooting

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 📘 How to Access Help in Trados Studio 2017
Who this is for
docs.text: Translators who want to quickly find support, tutorials, or solutions while working in Trados Studio 2017.

docs.title: What you need
docs.text:
• SDL Trados Studio 2017 installed
  • Internet connection (for online resources)

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open the Help ribbon
  2. At the top of the Trados window, click the Help tab.

  3. This ribbon is available in all views.

  4. Choose a help option

  5. Studio Blog → Articles and tips about using Trados.
  6. Knowledge Base (KB) → FAQs and troubleshooting guides.
  7. SDL Community → Online discussion forum with other users.
  8. Customer Feedback → Send feedback directly to SDL.

  9. Contact Support → Open the SDL TranslationZone support page.

  10. Download resources

  11. From the SDL TranslationZone, go to Learn & Support → Downloads.
  12. There you’ll find guides, updates, and additional tools.

docs.title: Result
docs.text: You can now access official documentation, community forums, and SDL support directly from within Trados.

docs.title: If things go wrong
docs.text:
• The Help ribbon doesn’t appear: Make sure you are on the latest service pack for Trados Studio 2017.
  • Links don’t open: Check your internet connection or try opening them in a separate browser.

Last updated: 2 Sept 2025

docs.title: 📘 How-To: Create a Project in Trados Studio 2017
Who this is for
docs.text: New translators who want a clean, repeatable setup.

docs.title: What you need
docs.text:
• Trados Studio 2017 installed
  • At least one source file (e.g., .docx)

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In the Welcome view, click New Project.
  2. Enter a Project name (e.g., Client_A_EN-DE).
  3. Choose Source language and Target language(s).
  4. Click Add Files → select your source documents → Next.
  5. Add or create a Translation Memory (TM).
  6. (Optional) Attach a Termbase if you use terminology.
  7. Review the summary → click Finish.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
Trados creates a project folder with your files and resources. You can open the files in the Editor and start translating.

🛈 Version note: Screens are from Trados 2017. Newer versions may rename or move some buttons.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: ⌨️ Reference: Common Keyboard Shortcuts in Trados Studio 2017
docs.text:
Use these shortcuts to work faster in the Editor view.

Action Shortcut (Windows) Confirm segment Ctrl+Enter Insert translation from memory Ctrl+T Copy source to target Ctrl+Insert Navigate to next segment Ctrl+↓ Navigate to previous segment Ctrl+↑ Undo last action Ctrl+Z Redo Ctrl+Y Search in translation memory F3

🛈 Version note: Shortcuts may vary in later Trados versions.

Last updated: 4 Sept 2025

docs.title: ⚡ Quick Start: Trados Studio 2017
docs.text:
Set up your first project in a few minutes.

  1. Open Trados Studio → you’ll see the Welcome screen.
  2. Click New Project to start the setup wizard.
  3. Choose your source language and target language(s).
  4. Click Add Files and select your source documents (e.g., Word).
  5. Add a translation memory (TM) (or create a new one).
  6. Click Finish → your project opens in the Editor.

Next: See How-To: Create a Project for more detail.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 1) “New Project” is greyed out
docs.text: Likely cause: No license activated. Fix: Go to Help → Product Activation and activate your license.

docs.title: 2) My translation memory isn’t available
docs.text: Likely cause: TM wasn’t attached during setup. Fix: Open Project Settings → Language Pairs → Translation Memories → Add your TM.

docs.title: 3) I can’t open my source file
docs.text: Likely cause: Unsupported or disabled file type. Fix: File → Options → File Types → make sure the file type is enabled.

docs.title: 4) I don’t see termbase results
docs.text:
Likely cause: No termbase attached. Fix: Project Settings → Language Pairs → Termbases → Add a termbase.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025
